title: CO Project Management Somalia
description:
The Work in Progress! Alliance is focused on unlocking the economic potential of young women and men in Egypt, Nigeria and Somalia.The project aims to enable them to generate sustainable and reasonable incomes  by finding regular employment or by them starting an enterprise.
The project has a holistic approach because a job alone does not guarantee a successful life in ones own country: 1)It is gender sensitive and inclusive: the programme aims to have 50% of the actively engaged youths be women. Forthe other 50% the programme focuses on the specific needs and participation of young men. 2) It focuses both on the supply and the demand in the labourmarket, and tries to link enterprises and job-seeking youths. 3) And it aims to change policies and develop an enabling environment: advocacy for enabling policies and having role models advocate for youth participation in decision making and at the labour market.
The most important goal of "Work in Progress!" is to improve the skills of young people and their economic prospects by creating jobs and stimulating entrepreneurship. The three major outcomes are as followed: 1) More young men and women have found paid jobs or are running their own enterprises. By improving their employability skills, improvetheir access to information, to exchange platforms to link them to business, accelerators and incubators, and financial investments. 2) Local SMEs see business grow resulting in newly created positions for youth. The project will improve the access to networks, knowledge and credit for Small and Medium Enterprises. 3) Policy measures adopted and implemented that are able to improve labor participation of youth (women in particular), and to promote a business environment. The project will involve influentialpeople in public and private sectors to take a lead in stimulating youth employment and business environment.

title: Maternity Clinic and Training Project
description:
Somalia has one of the highest maternal- and child mortality rates in the world. Long-lasting conflict has damaged the health sector and due to shortage of professional staff and low financial resources especially the most vulnerable people continue to str
uggle to receive quality healthcare. Since maternal healthcare services are not widely available majority of women don?t receive any professional healthcare during pregnancy and delivery which contributes to the high rates of maternal and infant mortality.
 Maternity Clinic and Training project has supported FinSom Maternity Clinic together with the local partner VMDSO in Afgoye Somalia since 2012. The Clinic provides maternal healthcare for thousands of women and treats about 20 000 outpatients annually. Th
e Clinic is the only one in the area operating free of cost and open 24/7. In addition to maternal health services the project aims to increase the awareness of health-related issues in the local community such as FGM HIV/AIDS provide support for the victi
ms of gender-based violence through counseling and organize training to traditional birth attendants. Long-term goal of the project is to improve women's health in Afgoye and ensure women's access to quality maternal healthcare. Main beneficiaries of the p
roject are the women receiving maternal healthcare and counseling at the Clinic and their children. Furthermore all the outpatients receiving care at the Clinic and people participating to the awareness raising are beneficiaries of the project. This includ
es vulnerable groups such as IDPs and disabled women. The results of the previous project phases show that the Clinic is providing vital source of quality care both to expectant mothers and other members of the community. Raising awareness about health has
 been successful and majority of pregnant women and mothers treated at the Clinic report negative attitude towards FGM. The continuation phase invests further to increase the capacity of local partner Clinic's health personnel TBAs and volunteers through t
raining so that in the future they could take over the management of the project and secure other sources of funding.

title: Rajo - youth employment and entrepreneurship project
description:
Rajo - youth employment and entrepreneurship project is a multi-actor joint project addressing high youth unemployment as well as lack of technical and vocational education and training (TVET) in Somaliland and Puntland. The project empowers especially you
th in a vulnerable position. The development goal is to increase youth employment rate in the project areas. By providing vocational trainings the project also responses to the huge demand for labor in technical fields. Outcomes are:- Youth in a vulnerable
 position gain vocational skills and work experience in the sectors that have demand for labor- Quality of vocational education in partner schools increases- Communities value vocational skills and training more than beforeMain outputs + activities include
:- Vocational teachers trained in pedagogical skills: 2 intensive trainings + on-line guidance- Vocational training programs incl. entrepreneurship skills offered locally for youth in vulnerable position; 18 short trainings for 360 students- Students of vo
cational trainings done internship in local companies; min. 300 students done internship- Positive examples of vocationally trained youth and information of income possibilities with vocational education shared in the communities; awareness raising campaig
ns graduation giftsThe project is implemented in 3 areas. For the implementation FSN has 6 NGO partners incl. 3 member NGOs in Finland and for pedagogical vocational teaching development 1 university partner Hame UAS HAMK from Finland and 2 TVET centers/wo
rkshops from Somalia. The cooperative model that FSN has developed since 2012 enforces civil society and enhances stability. The beneficiaries of the project incl. youth aged 15-25 in the project areas especially youth in vulnerable position e.g. youth of 
ethnic or clan minorities internally displaced persons persons with disabilities. Also teachers of the vocational trainings local NGO + school partners are direct beneficiaries. Indirect beneficiaries include the families of the students and teachers local
 companies and finally the communities with an estimated population of 1 150 000.

title: Mobiiliterveysklinikka - Daryeel-hanke II Somaliassa Afmadowssa
description:
Daryeel Mobile Health Clinic II is a continuation project which promotes health services in southern Somalia. The project continues its work in the rural areas through a mobile clinic and simultaneously focuses on capacity building of local partner to ensu
re the sustainability of the project to raise awareness of female genital mutilation (FGM) and to improve equal rights of people with disabilities (PWD) to basic health care services. The Mobile Health Clinic 2018-2020 provides primary health care in rural
 areas outside and inside of Afmadow town in Jubaland Somalia. The project is implemented in cooperation with the Finland-Somalia Association FSA a local partner SAHDA and the Ministry of Health of Jubaland. The Mobile Health Clinic strengthens the area's 
healthcare and access to basic services. The project aims to bring health services close to communities where access to and travel to health services is difficult. The project provides free primary healthcare services such as consultations medicines midwif
ery kits and mosquito nets. The project strengthens the local partner's capacity in healthcare and local disease prevention and in project management through trainings and continuous capacity building from Finland by health care and project management expe
rts. The project serves the whole population crossing the clan borders and reaches especially women and children under five. The continuation project 2021-22 continues to promote the health of women children and communities. As a result: 1. The health of r
emote communities especially of women and children has improved through the services of mobile health clinic. 2. The awareness of the impacts of female genital mutilation has increased amongst village midwives.3. The awareness of the staff and village midw
ives on health and disability has increased and they reach basic health care more easily.4. The sustainability of the project is ensured through trainings technical support networking and dissemination of information of mobile health clinic's work and achi
evementFSA has a long experience in health projects in Somalia. The sustainability of the projects has been ensured.

title: FCA: Mideeye Support of the National Reconciliation and Local Governance in Somalia
description:
Inclusive decision-making processes and trust towards the government institutions are necessery when building a stable and peaceful Somalia. Finn Church Aid (FCA) in partnership with the Network for Religious and Traditional Peacemakers is implementing a  
Mideeye project. The project works for a more stable and peaceful Somalia recognizing that genuine national reconciliation and inclusive governance are two reinforcing and interrelated processes crucial for peace and state building.  FCA and the Network fo
r Religious and Traditional Peacemakers have been active in mediation and local-level democratization and institution building in Somalia for several years. Since 2017 FCA has supported the ministry responsible for the implementation of the National Reconc
iliation Framework (NRF) at the request of the Somali government. Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland has supported the FCA?s reconciliation project with 13 million Euros during the years 2018-2021. External evaluation from the year 2020 states that th
e project has been highly successful in achieving the central objective to establish a NRF and to advance reconciliation. Funding for Mideeye project is part of MFA's Country Programme for Somalia. Mideeye project is in line with Country Programme's object
ives concerning state building and peace building. The support for the Mideeye project is 45 million euros for the years 2021-2024.

title: Somalian opetussektorin kehittaminen
description:
Finland supports the education sector in Somalia through Education and Learning programme component of the UNICEF's Country Programme for Somalia (2021-2025).The Outcome of the Education Programme is to ensure that more children especially girls from the m
ost disadvantaged communities and those affected by crises and conflict access quality pre-primary and basic education with improved learning outcomes. The Education Programme is in line with the first Impact Area of Finland?s Country Programme for Somalia
 2021-2024: Improved confidence in the state and increased social cohesion for a renewed social contract through state-building reconciliation and service delivery in health- and education sectors. Finland supports UNICEF's Education Programme in Somalia w
ith 765 million Euros during the years 2021-2024.

title: HALO/Humanitaarinen miinatoiminta Somaliassa
description:
In Somalia HALO will conduct clearance of mines and other explosive devices especially near the Somali-Ethiopian border provide risk education assist victims of mines and support Somali authorities in ammunition management. The project will support and str
engthen Somalia?s security stability and development through humanitarian mine action and stockpile destruction. HALO?s project seeks to enhance human security and reduce civilian accidents and casualties by limiting the impact and proliferation of explosi
ve items. It also aims at contributing to socioeconomic development and reducing displacement. The project supports peace building by strengthening local institutions and contributing to increased stability. The beneficiaries of the project are local commu
nities settled in areas where HALO conducts mine clearance and stockpile destruction. Finland will support HALO?s project in Somalia during 2021-2025 with 15 million euros.

title: Renewable Energy Skills Training and Women Economic Development
description: The proposed project has two thematic focuses in the Somali region: renewable energy and women’s economic empowerment. This project seeks to unlock the potential of Somalia’s renewable energy sector. Expanding energy access in the country has the potential to increase the productivity and competitiveness of Somali businesses, contribute to alleviating poverty (both of which could lead to increased investment), improve health and education outcomes, and bolster security. Women’s Economic Empowerment gives women the independence, confidence, and ability to transform their lives. There is a direct correlation between improvements in health, education, peace, and security and the eventual success of women entrepreneurs to catalyse change within their regions, clans, towns, and families. Developing women’s economic empowerment and renewable energy is critical in building wealth, creating jobs, and unleashing the potential for innovation that attracts investment and helps every nation develop.

title: African Cities Research Programme
description: Research which will produce new operationally-relevant knowledge and evidence on African ‘cities as systems’. The research will help policy makers and those who manage cities to tackle the most significant problems constraining growth and development in individual African Cities, leading to the development of, and investment in, more effective economic development and poverty-reduction policies and programmes in African cities, by FCDO and its partners.

implementing: International Institute for Environment and Development

title: Maternity Clinic and Training Project
description:
Long-running conflict has destroyed the infrastructure of the Somali state and the country has one of the worst health indicators in the world. The high-risk groups are 2.4 million children under age 5 and more than 3 million women of child-bearing age. Ac
cording to WHO the maternal mortality ratio is 732 per 100 000 live births although most of the maternal deaths would be preventable. Rebuilding the health sector is challenged by a shortage of professional staff financial resources and effective governanc
e and NGOs have played a key role in providing with these services. African Care?s Maternity Clinic and Training project has since its start in 2012 supported the development of the FinSom maternity clinic together with the local partner VMDSO. Results sho
w that the service of the clinic has decreased maternal mortality rate prevalence of tetanus raised awareness about exclusive breast feeding and FGM. The clinic is well-known in Afgoye and surrounding areas and a vital source of quality maternal health car
e for both expectant mothers and the community. Hence the maternal health care services are continued also in the continuation phase of the project.The project at hand seeks to further enhance the capacity and services of the partner and the clinic so that
 eventually maternal health services could be provided without development cooperation funding. This is done by investing in the education and training of the VMDSO staff and health workers and monitoring the long-term impact of the trainings. Simultaneous
ly invaluable information on the key challenges and development needs will be mapped out and used for future trainings.  Also the support of the sexual violence victims will be intensified. It will be expanded to an in-person counselling in addition to the
 telephone support. Open-access seminars and family counselling are likewise continued and further intensified. Seminars about gender equality family planning and gender-based violence work to dismantle unequal social structures through open dialogue. Proj
ect's beneficiaries are women in labour children victims of sexual violence clinic?s personnel and partner organization VMDSO.

title: Sahansaho ? against desertification in Somalia
description:
The key development problem which the project aims to find solutions to is the desertification leading to lack of livelihoods poverty and forced migration. The objective is sustainable use of natural resources and secured livelihood in the project areas. T
he project started in 2012 and it has been planned for 10 years. This continuation project will be its 4th and final phase.The outcomes of 2019-2022 will be:1. Environmental centers developed into regional hubs2. Educational institutions and trainers have 
expertise to provide environmental education3. Resilience of local communities to climate change and drought improved4. Implementation of policies related to natural resource management (NRM)The outputs will be: 1.1. Seedlings of locally successful species
 produced planted distributed and sold per year 1.2. Seed collection stands established and local availability of the seeds of the most important species secured 1.3. Operating models for the environmental centers developed 2.1. Trainers trained and traini
ng material produced 2.2. Training materials and research opportunities provided to universities and environmental education material provided to teachers 3.1. Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced in local communities 3.2. Agroforestry practices and s
oil and water conservation techniques adopted in local communities 4.1.  Network of the environmental actors built and environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated at all project sites 4.2.  Policy reviews and briefs produced for policy dialogu
e with ministries of environment and implementation of environmental policies startedThe project is implemented at 3 sites in Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partners in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil
 society in Somalia and creates new networks  that also promote peace and stability.The beneficiaries are local communities authorities and educational institutions among others.

title: Ramaad - environment relief project in Somalia
description:
Ramaad is a joint project coordinated by the Finnish Somalia Network  (FSN) with its partners addressing the sustainable use and management  of the natural resources in Somalia and desertification that leads to  loss of livelihoods poverty and forced migra
tion. The project started  in 2014 and is planned for 10 years. This is its 4th and final phase.  The long-term objective is sustainable use and management of natural  resources and secured livelihood in the project areas.The outcomes are:1.    3 environme
ntal centers developed into regional hubs with own income2.    Environmental education and awareness increased in project areas3.    Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced by making energy saving  stoves locally available4.    Capacity of administration
s to formulate and implement  environmental policies has increased and implementation of the  policies has startedThe main outputs are:- 30 000 seedlings of locally successful species produced planted  distributed and sold- 90 seed collection stands establ
ished and local availability of the  seeds of the most important species secured- Operating models for the 3 environmental centers developed  partners' capacity to carry out business activities built and  feasibility study for stove fabrication workshops p
repared- Environmental awareness of the local communities and environmental  education in schools increased- 3 stove manufacturing workshops established and 18 craftsmen trained- Environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated- Implementation of e
nvironmental policies at district and local level startedThe project is implemented in three areas in southern and central  Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partner NGOs  in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the ci
vil  society and enhances stability. The project areas are:1. Guriel and Dhusamareeb Galmudug2. El-Adde Gedo/Jubbaland3. Afmadow Lower Jubba/Jubbaland

title: Support project for freedom of expression journalism and public service broadcasting in Somalia
description:
The continuation phase of Vikes Somalia project supports the Somali national TV channel to develop towards editorially an independent public service broadcaster and assists the national journalist union to become a representative trade union of media worke
rs across Somalia.By providing journalist training and technical support the project seeks to 1) improve the production process and quality of news and other programmes at Somali National Television (SNTV) 2) improve the awareness of media rights and respo
nsibilities and safety of Somali journalists and 3) improve professional skills of women journalists.Project activities include the introduction of regular children?s programme production at SNTV. The project will support the preparation of a journalist co
de of conduct and the drafting of a by-law on public service broadcasting.About 300 journalists across the country will be trained in practical journalism skills media rights and security and professional ethics.The project is based on peer learning. Journ
alists are trained by more experienced Finnish and Somali journalists. Local technicians are trained by experienced Finnish technical experts. Local cameramen and video editors are trained by experienced visiting multimedia professionals from Finland.Main 
cooperation partners are Somali Ministry of Information and the National Union of Somali Journalists. Joint training activities will also be arranged with Somaliland Journalists Association (SOLJA).

title: Health and Education Sector Development through Skills and Knowledge Transfer in South Central Somalia
description:
The project aims at improving the capacity of public sector health and education institutions to provide quality services with special focus on vulnerable groups: women children and youth through skills and knowledge transfer by the Somali diaspora. The ov
erall objective of the project is to contribute to stabilization in South Central Somalia and Puntland through increasing access to basic services (health and education) and creating employment opportunities for the youth including women. In addition young
 Somalis will be placed in internship positions under the supervision of the diaspora experts at relevant institutions. The project trains health and education sector professionals to produce quality public services in health and education and to administe
r the resources of the sectors. The trainers are diaspora experts especially Finnish diaspora who work and share their expertise in the sectors.The Mid-Term Evaluation which was finalized in August 2018 showed that results have been gained in both health a
nd education sectors. For example the intake of patients at Yardimeli Hospital in Mogadishu has increased significantly in a short period of time from around 800 patients in July 2017 to around 4000 in March 2018. Moreover the number of assisted births inc
reased substantially. The diaspora experts placed at the Ministry of Education were successful in supporting the organizational reform and writing key strategic planning documents for the sector. According to the Mid-Term Evaluation the project was very re
levant in filling the gaps and specialized needs in the institutions. According to all participants both local and the diaspora the project was successful in producing sustainable results in skills and knowledge. The implementing partner is the Internation
al Organisation for Migration (IOM). From 2015 to 2019 Finland has supported the project with 4 420 000 EUR. From 2019 to 2021 the total budget for the second phase funded by Finland is 5 400 000 EUR. The budget is disbursed as follows: 1 MEUR in 2019; 24 
MEUR in 2020; 2 MEUR in 2021.

title: Multi-Partner Fund for Somalia (MPF)
description:
World Bank's Multi-Partner Fund (MPF) supports Somalia's stabilization and peacebuilding by strengthening Somalia's governance and the management of the state's revenues (including taxation) as well as by reviving the country's economy and the private sect
or to allow increased state revenues through taxation and to provide resources for extended and improved public services. In the project level the funded projects focus around four thematic priority areas which include government's key functions; productiv
e sectors and employment; infrastructure development; as well as management of natural resources and resilience. For example the Fund can support the payment of Somalia's government officials' salaries and improve the public financial management systems; b
oost the productivity and the value chains of potential productive sectors and improve youth employment (allowing also greater tax revenues); improve the infrastructure and therefroe improve the productivity among else in the energy sector; and strengthen 
the resilience of selected groups and professions such as cattle herders/pastoralists.The Fund also supports one of Finland's priority sectors the Health sector by strengthening health governance's salary payment and financial management systems as well as
 by supporting the governance capacity in the sector.The Fund operates in close partnership with the Federal Government of Somalia as well as with the donors and international agencies through the New Deal framework and through its aid infrastructure Somal
ia Development and Reconstruction Facility (SDRF) offering peace and statebuilding support to the Somali transition process. Finland together with other international partners has committed itself to work increasingly through the New Deal structures.Finlan
d supports the MPF over the period of 2016-2019 with 4MEUR which is disbursed as follows: 2016: 2MEUR 2018: 1MEUR 2019: 1MEUR.

title: Public-Private-People: Joint and Inclusive Effort Against Tuberculosis in Somalia
description:
The project builds on the previous TB intervention implemented by LSV. However in order to increase effectiveness totally new strategies will be applied.TB continues to be an essential health problem in Somalia. The disease hasn't been beaten yet but rathe
r new problems emerge such as multi-drug resistant forms of TB resulting in much more complex treatment regimens and bigger danger to the population.LSV will continue to diagnose and treat TB patients in Hargeisa and Mogadishu. As a new strategy the privat
e sector health care providers (clinics and pharmacies) and local communities will be engaged in the effort in a systematic way in order to strengthen a holistic public-private-people partnership approach to tackling the disease. In addition collaboration 
with the local maternity and child health facility network will be strengthened. The overall objective is to contribute to the reduction of TB burden and suffering in Somalia. The immediate objectives of the project include 1) To increase TB awareness and 
participation of communities in TB control. 2) To increase TB awareness and participation of private practitioners and pharmacists in TB control in. 3) To diagnose and treat patients at two TB centers according to WHO's DOTS protocol. 4) To provide TB cult
ure services and drug susceptibility tests (DST) for suspected MDR cases.Regarding the cross-cutting themes the project will empower women and facilitate their access to TB services. In addition the project will reduce inequality by providing an access to 
TB services for internally displaced persons (IDPs). When it comes to climate proofing there are no negative impacts on environment. For example thanks to community DOTS there will be less daily traveling to TB Centers.The main project partners include NGO
 called PSR and National TB Programs (NTPs). LSV will strengthen their capacity in all the fields described above.The main beneficiaries include local people of Hargeisa Mogadishu and nomads living in nearby areas who have TB or belong to risk groups. The 
project will help the poorest of the poor. For example many cases are found among people who suffer from malnutrition.

title: Hiil hooyo - maternal healthcare project
description:
Hiil hooyo is a multi-actor joint project addressing maternal healthcare in Somaliland and Puntland. The key development problem is high maternal mortality having multiple negative effects. Maternal mortality rate in the project areas is one of the highest
 in the world. The project seeks to enhance women's right and the right of persons with disabilities to maternal healthcare. The project started in 2017 with a pilot phase and the new phase aims to make the results sustainable.The main outcomes are:1. Skil
ls and motivation of healthcare workers improved2. Number of mothers and children attending MCHs increased3. Attendance and accessibility of persons with disabilities to MCHs increased4. Partner universities able to conduct independently e-learning program
 in maternal healthcare and students benefitted from the developed materialThe main outputs and activities include:- 240 healthcare workers passed in-service training on maternal healthcare; 4 trainings- 10 000 persons reached by awareness raising programs
; village meetings school classes media campaigns home visits fathers? clubs- 460 persons trained on the rights of persons with disabilities; training of trainers workshops- 120 university students passed e-learning program in maternal healthcare teachers 
trained and partner universities networking; e-course for students on-line training for teachers joint meetingsThe project is implemented in 10 districts in 3 areas. For the implementation the FSN has 6 NGO partners of which 3 its member organizations in F
inland and 5 university partners of which 2 (Diak and Xamk) in Finland. In addition the Disability Partnership Finland (DPF) offers expertize for disability issues. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil society and enhances stability.The bene
ficiaries of the project include healthcare workers pregnant and breastfeeding mothers with their families persons with disabilities university lecturers and students students in secondary schools the NGO partners and indirectly communities in general in t
he project areas with an estimated population of 15 million.

title: HALO/Humanitarian Mine Action in Somalia
description:
HALO?s project will support and strengthen Somalia?s security stability and development through humanitarian mine action and stockpile destruction. HALO?s project seeks to 1) contribute to the human security and reduce civilian accidents and casualties by 
limiting the impact and proliferation of explosive items 2) contribute to the peace dividend and assist fragile communities in their own efforts to reinstate a working and stable society and 3) reduce poverty and hunger by removing blockage to high priorit
y infrastructure water access and roads. The project takes place in two phases: First completing the manual clearance of Somaliland at which point mine action in Somaliland will become completely owned funded and implemented by national authorities with su
fficient capacity to tackle any residual tasking. Finland has supported this project since 2003. Second HALO will seek and destroy community held or abandoned stockpiles of ammunition held outside of state control across their area of operations in Souther
n Somalia. The primary beneficiaries of the project are local populations in areas where HALO will conduct mine clearance and stockpile destruction. Finland will support HALO?s project in Somalia during 2017-2020 with one million euros.

title: UNFPA Somalia Wellbeing of Women and Girls
description:
Support to the UN Population Fund's (UNFPA) country programme continues Finland's strong contribution for the development of Somalia's reproductive maternal and child health care services. UNFPA has been among the three UN agencies that have been involved 
in the UN Joint Nutrition and Health Programme in Somalia (JHNP) which focused on the development of maternal and child health services. Finland supported the implementation of the programme for 15.5MEUR between 2014-2016. JHNP has provided services for an
 area covering half of Somalia's population. It has reached good results having significantly contributed to the reduction of maternal and infant mortality. Through JHNP UNFPA has supported the provision of maternal sexual and reproductive health services 
as well as contributed to improving their quality. UNFPA has supported the running of 135 maternal clinics; the training of midwifes in 15 midwiferies throughout Somalia; the provision of training on reproductive health for over 600 health care professiona
ls; as well as the provision of technical assistance to the ministries of health to support their capacity building including their work on health sector strategic development. As JHNP is coming to an end in early-2017 UNFPA continues the work to develop t
he reproductive maternal and child health care in Somalia according to its mandate.UNFPA country strategy for Somalia for 2011-2016 has been extended for one year to cover also 2017. Its overall objective is to improve the wellbeing of Somali people. The c
ountry strategy aims to achieve this through reducing maternal mortality and through supporting the realization of reproductive rights and services. In addition the strategy supports gender equality and combats gender-based violence as well as strengthens 
the Somali statistical systems and promotes evidence-based planning and policy design.Three particular priority areas have been identified for 2017:1.Increased provision of comprehensive sexual and reproductive health services (around 50% of the annual bud
get for 2017)2.Promotion of gender equality and prevention of gender-based violence (around 25% of the 2017 budget)3.Strengthened national capacity on use of quality disaggregated data for evidence-based planning and policy design on population and develop
ment issues (around 25% of the 2017 budget)Finland supports the implementation of the UNFPA Somalia country strategy for 2011-2017 for 2 million euros.

title: Somaliland Health Sector Support (MIDA Finnsom IV)
description:
IOM MIDA Finnsom IV project focuses on contributing to improved health outcomes in Somaliland and particularly its remote regions. To achieve this the project supports the capacity of public sector institutions to provide quality health services. Three out
puts have been defined:1.) Local health professionals have skills/capacity to deliver quality health services2.) Local health training institutions have improved competence and ability to train local health professionals 3.) Ministry of Health has increase
d capacity to steer manage and coordinate the health sector The Somali diaspora experts particularly the Finnish Somali diaspora experts are the actors in the capacity building efforts. They train the local health professionals and participate in developin
g strategies plans standards and curricula for health sector. Particular attention is given to women's and child health. In the long term the project is expected to contribute to better health outcomes for Somaliland population and especially the health ou
tcomes for women and children.The first Finnish funded MIDA project was initiated already in 2008. The project has been evaluated twice and the findings suggest that the project has significantly strengthened public health institutions? ability to provide 
quality services in Somaliland. The findings and recommendations of evaluations have been duly notified in the planning of the Finnsom IV phase: For example the project now focuses on the more remote regions in Somaliland where service provision is poorer 
than in the capital Hargeisa. Similarly following the recommendations the length of the assignments of diaspora experts has been increased for Phase IV.To support the implementation of the project the National Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) also im
plements tailored trainings for the Ministry of Health.The duration of the Phase IV is four years from March 2017 until February 2021. The budget for the project is 4 300 000 Euros. Somalia is considered an LDC country.

title: CO-Drought Response in Somaliland
description:
The latest findings from a countrywide seasonal assessment conducted in December 2016 by the Famine Early Warning Systems Network indicate that over 2.9 million people face Crisis and Emergency (IPC Phases 3 and 4) across Somalia through June 2017. Somalia President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmajo declared the drought a national disaster on 28 February 2017.
Drought affected families are resorting to a range of negative coping strategies including reducing the number of meals eaten in a given day, skipping meals, accumulation of debts or obtaining food on credit from shops, as well as migration in search of livelihood. IDPs rely heavily on support from the host community. Besides, the maternal mortality rate for Somalia is among the highest in the world at 732 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. Water shortage may also trigger further outbreak of water borne diseases.
Oxfam provides integrated EFSVL (Emergency Food Security and Vulnerable Livelihoods) and WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene) support to vulnerable women, men, boys and girls affected by drought in Sool, Sanaag, Toghdeer and Awdal regions as an immediate life saving intervention whilst taking steps to ensure the response contributes to the capacity building and resilience of communities and partners. Gender and protection will be mainstreamed throughout the response. The key EFSVL interventions include the distribution of cash grants to households who have lost their livestock and financial support to the Ministry of Livestock for scale upof livestock mass vaccination, control of parasites, disease surveillance and treatment of clinical cases. The key WASH interventions include the protection and development of spring and shallow wells, provision of water supply through trucking and vouchers, construction of communal latrines, hygiene promotion activities and distribution of hygiene materials.

title: Drought Response in Somaliland
description:
The latest findings from a countrywide seasonal assessment conducted in December 2016 by the Famine Early Warning Systems Network indicate that over 2.9 million people face Crisis and Emergency (IPC Phases 3 and 4) across Somalia through June 2017. Somalia President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmajo declared the drought a national disaster on 28 February 2017.
Drought affected families are resorting to a range of negative coping strategies including reducing the number of meals eaten in a given day, skipping meals, accumulation of debts or obtaining food on credit from shops, as well as migration in search of livelihood. IDPs rely heavily on support from the host community. Besides, the maternal mortality rate for Somalia is among the highest in the world at 732 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. Water shortage may also trigger further outbreak of water borne diseases.
Oxfam provides integrated EFSVL (Emergency Food Security and Vulnerable Livelihoods) and WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene) support to vulnerable women, men, boys and girls affected by drought in Sool, Sanaag, Toghdeer and Awdal regions as an immediate life saving intervention whilst taking steps to ensure the response contributes to the capacity building and resilience of communities and partners. Gender and protection will be mainstreamed throughout the response. The key EFSVL interventions include the distribution of cash grants to households who have lost their livestock and financial support to the Ministry of Livestock for scale upof livestock mass vaccination, control of parasites, disease surveillance and treatment of clinical cases. The key WASH interventions include the protection and development of spring and shallow wells, provision of water supply through trucking and vouchers, construction of communal latrines, hygiene promotion activities and distribution of hygiene materials.

title: CO-Somalia Twinning  Programme
description:
Over the past few years, #localising humanitarian aid# has been regularly raised as a necessity to fundamentally reform the humanitarian system to respond more effectively and equitably to today#s complex crises. The 2016 World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) brought together old and new voices for local humanitarian leadership, creating a space and momentum to speak out and bring change to the system, resulting in The Grand Bargain commitments to advance the localization agenda. In parallel, the Charter4Change, signed on to bymany INGOs, including Oxfam, further commits to reforming the humanitarian system to ensure greater influence and funding for localand national NGOs.

The Somalia NGO Consortium (SNC) and Oxfam Somalia are supporting this movement byplanning and implementing activities to more equitable shift and share power, knowledge, and resources between local, national and international humanitarian actors involved in Somalia#s humanitarian response, with a particular focus on supporting women#srights organisations (WROs) and addressing deeply embedded gender inequities. The SNC#s Strategy 2017-2019 includes as an outcome a #25 per cent of direct funding to Somalia Local NGOs and increased voice and representation with donors, United Nations (UN) and International NGO (INGO) by 2019#. Oxfam Somalia#s humanitarian influencing strategy 2018-2020 aims in its first objective at having more #effective and timely localised aid# to support drought and conflict affected populations. In the strategy, Oxfam Somalia aims to implement the localization agenda in a way that can help address Somalia women#s rights and gender justice and be a powerful agent of women#s transformative leadership in Somalia.

title: SOS Kinderdorpen-Somalia Joint Response
description: The Joint Response for Somalia is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. Oxfam Novib is leading a consortium that consists of Dorcas, SOS Children#s Villages, World Vision and Oxfam Novib. The proposed projectaims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistance to reduce acute humanitarian need for communities affected by the drought and protracted conflict. The (revised) Humanitarian Response Plan, dated July 2018, states there are currently 5,4 mln people in need. The locations and sectors for project implementation are to be determined in a planning workshop taking place on 24 and 25 October, with representatives from the participating consortium members and local partners.

title: HO-Somalia Joint Response II
description: The Joint Response for Somalia is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. In 2020, Oxfam Novib is leading a consortium that consists of Help a Child/ Medair, SOS Children#s Villages, World Vision and Oxfam Novib. The project aims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistanceto reduce acute humanitarian needs for communities affected by the drought and protracted conflict. The 2020 Joint Response has been designed in line with existing needs relevant to geography, sectors, as well as member#s expertise. Members will continue to implement in the same sectors as the SOMJR 2019: Food Security and Livelihoods, WASH, Health, Nutrition, Protection and Multi-Purpose Cash.

title: Somalia Joint Response II
description: The Somalia Joint Response is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. The Consortium consists of four INGOs and six LNGOs and is led by Oxfam Novib. The four INGOs are: Oxfam Novib, Red een Kind, WorldVision and SOS Children#s Villages. The six LNGOs are: TASCO, Havoyoco, Candlelight, ZamZam, Dawa, KAALO. The Somalia Joint Response is present in Somaliland, Puntland and South Central (Mogadishu, Banadir). The proposed project aims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistance to reduce acute humanitarian need for communities affectedby the drought and protracted conflict. The Somalia Joint Response 2020 is a continuation of the response in 2019, and will focus on the following sectors: FSL, Protection, WASH, Health and Nutrition. A special focus will be on localisation and supporting LNGOs in capacity strengthening and becoming the lead of future responses. Improved accountability to affected populations will underpin the work of the response. The response will also subgrant the Somalia NGO Consortium for activities around localisation, risk management and coordination.

title: CO-Somalia Resilience Program
description:
The program promotes bottom-up and top-down governance capacity development.  At HH and group level, the program will continue to expand the number of VSLAs, increasing the number of these social capital-developing and integration-promoting mechanisms.  Through the intensive GCVCA facilitated assessment process and subsequent development of CAAPs, SomReP will continue to place the community at the forefront of analyzing their own challenges and opportunities, and putting forth their own priorities and plans to help them better plan for and mitigate against shocks and promote food security and economic development.  The CAAP is the foundation for development planning at the community level, assisting community leadership to identify and prioritize development actions. Other organizations and consortia are also developing plans at community and district level; as such, SomReP will continue to jointly plan and coordinate actions at both Technical Unit and site level so as to ensure efficient use of multipledonors# resources in fulfillment of community needs.
In partnership with district and Member State line ministries, SomReP will undertake sector specific assessments targeting systems (e.g. water systems, market systems) which affect resilience buildingwithin and between villages.  During times of shock, SomReP will mobilize resources to partner with relevant line ministries to undertake assessment to support early response and post-shock recovery.  Village and village-cluster plans will be aggregated and support the development of district-level planning frameworks.  Through direct support to line ministries through secondments and other facilitative actions, the program will promote understanding of national and Member State Level frameworks (NDP andRRF) at the community planning level.  As Member State line ministries are supported to monitor uptake and progress towards achieving disaster risk management actions at community level, the government will both fulfill its mandate and begin to strengthen its ability to do this independently.

title: CO-Learning champions among Oxfam projec
description: This project will strengthen learning within Oxfam as well as from local partnerships. It#s hoped that entailing local partners, documenting and sharing learnings from Oxfam-Partner and Partner-Partner interactions will prioritize the southern agenda. The developed tools will become part of the overall MEAL tools and the info-graphs and short videos will ensure that knowledge is shared throughout Oxfam and with partners

title: CO-Enhancing Resilience in Somaliland
description:
This project is aimed to enhance community resilience in Berbera area, as part of  bigger SOMREP effort in promoting resilience across Somalia and somaliland.
This Project focus on community capacity development to withstand shocks and stresses with particular focus on drought hazard.
key pilers of the project includes VSLAs establishment at community level: development community action plan,enhance youth entrepreneurship   and support on marketable IGAs.  The project will support access to food security at household level through provision  of agricultural input  to potential farmers. A Total of 30,000 people are expected to benefit this project fora period of one year.

title: CO-integrated humanitarian Somalia respo
description:
About 4.6 million people in Somalia are food insecure and 4.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance. The reduction in the number of people in need since early 2018 has been attributed to favourable rainfall during the Gu season (April to June) and sustained humanitarian assistance. Over 1.5 million people face acute food security Crisis or worse (IPC Phase 3 or higher) and approximately 3.1 million people are Stressed (IPC 2)1. Although the 2016/2017 drought has ended in most parts of Somalia, its adverse impact lingers among those who were impoverished or displaced, and pastoralists who lost all or most of their livestock, particularly in the north. Without sustained food and livelihood assistance, the latter are likely to remain in Emergency (IPC 4).
While acute malnutrition rates have improved nationally to Serious from Critical, the overall prevalence of acute malnutrition remains largely unchanged from Deyr 2017/2018. Between August and December, 294,000 acutely malnourished children, including 55,000 severe cases, aged underfive, will require treatment and integrated support. The acute malnutrition burden over the next 12 months is projected to be 588,400 acutely malnourished children, including 110,500 severe cases. The persistently high levels of acute malnutrition are unlikely toreduce without addressing the underlying causes, particularly in internally displaced persons (IDP) settlements and in some rural areas

title: CO-Somalia Drought Response (Marisla)
description:
Somalia has experienced recurrent droughts since 2011 which have been increasingly exacerbated by climate change. Agro-pastoralistsand pastoralists have been badly affected by the 2019 drought which has caused widespread crop failure, water shortages, and depleted livestock levels.
More than 4.2 million people were estimated to be in need of humanitarian assistance in 2019, and the number ofpeople who are food insecure is expected to increase in the coming months.  This year#s severe drought has been caused by abnormally hot, dry conditions during January-March and the failure of the rains in April-June. Most households are already adopting negativecoping strategies to mitigate food insecurity, including reducing food intake. Poor transportation and market infrastructure make it difficult for pastoralists to access markets, and there are few fed markets to provide animals with nutrition when natural pastures are inadequate. Over 80% of livestock was lost as a result of the 2017 drought, and the population of livestock herds, essential for pastoralists# food and income, have not yet recovered.
The impact of the 2019 drought on the water and sanitation sector has beensignificant. Water supply (boreholes, shallow wells) is severely limited and the cost of accessing water has increased sharply, representing a severe burden on insufficient household income. Existing groundwater sources contain a highly mineralized content, rendering it unsuitable for drinking, but a prior Oxfam needs assessment showed that the vast majority of households in the project area do not treat their water. Open defecation remains common, increasing protection risks for women and girls who venture outside alone or during the night or move far from dwellings to known open defecation areas.
Oxfam aims to assist at least 500,000 affected peoplewith immediate food security and WASH programming along with resilience and recovery interventions to diminish the impact of recurring droughts on vulnerable populations. Oxfam will embed activities to strengthen the protection of women, men, boys, and girls within the EFSVL and WASH workstreams.

title: CO-DRA POC Development Process Somalia
description:
Core Humanitarian Standard, evidence-based and that meets needs holistically by integrating a triple nexus approach. This model will be peer-reviewed by other experts in the Global South. Once further funding is secured, it will become operational, with multiple organizations making varied, layered contributions to common outcomes according to their strengths # to ensure humanitarian responses uphold interwoven development and peace objectives and are thereby sustainable and transformative.
Additionally, the platform willproduce a robust operating procedure for its Anticipatory Response Fund, which serves as an emergency response mechanism/crisis modifier. Many INGOs, including Oxfam in Myanmar and Bangladesh, have successfully piloted this response mechanism with local partners.Upon request by local partners, the Somalia Joint Response is also piloting this mechanism with local partners in 2020, and all SOMJR INGOs have included a crisis modifier in their budgets in 2020. The Anticipatory Response Fund serves as a means for local humanitarian partners to quickly access funding to respond to sudden crises and emergencies. The fund's aim is to address funding gaps andensure quick access to emergency funding for local responders. The fund will build oncurrent initiatives in country to promote local humanitarian leadership and preparedness, and deliver on commitments made in the Grand Bargain and Charter for Change by donor andNGO signatories. It will also identify strengths and areas for capacity development in relation to emergency response in Somalia The operating procedure for the Anticipatory Response Fund will include triggers and related protocols, such that a pilot test of triggers, collaboration mechanisms and protocols can take place ahead ofthe humanitarian response windows, in the second half of 2020.
Beyond the pilot phase, these actions will lay the foundations for a response mechanism that is pre-emptive and therefore efficient and highly responsive # improving the quality of locally-led humanitarian response in Somalia and Somaliland. Delivering on the ambition statement (i.e. development of above-mentioned model for humanitarian programming and operating procedures) will contribute to all four DRA strategic priorities: 1) more effective support for locally-led responses by supporting Nexus as locally-led platform; 2) innovation and learning by generating knowledge outputs and new ways of working; 3) collaboration for increased effectiveness by bringing together a wide range of localactors with coverage of all 9 regions of Somalia and Somaliland; and 4) more accountable humanitarian action by giving voice and decision making power to local organisations and adding rigor through South-South peer review.

title: Citizenship Project
description:
The Ministry of Parliamentary Relations and Constitutional Affairs #MoPCA# has been conducting awareness programs aimed at educating citizens about their constitutional rights and their obligations. Thus far, MoPCA has implemented an awareness programs, which arenow broadcast on Radio and TV. The radio program has a wide coverage of people as it reaches almost all over the country. Furthermore, MoPCA has signed agreement with the Ministry of Education and Science as regards incorporating civic educationcourses into the curriculum of high primary schools, secondary schools and universities. The curriculum for the three preceding streams has been finalized recently and the teaching of the civic education is expected to begin soon.
In addition, MoPCA intends to train all government institutions to ensure that such institutions respect the constitutional rights of the citizens. The essence of the training of the government institutions on the constitutional rights is to enhance the protection of basic human rights and to strengthen the rule of law. So far, MoPCA has trained the Good Governance and Anti Corruption Commission as well as 1000 young men who were undertaking their National Service training at Dararweyne training school. The ministry also visited regional universities to train National Service girls who were attached to different universities to complete their national service requirements. MoPCA will continue training other government institutions on constitutional rights of the citizens.
Similarly, the Ministry has also distributed large quantities of the copies of the constitution as well as brochures and pamphlets aimed at raising citizens# awareness vis-à-vis their constitutional rights and their obligations as well. The ministry is also planning to visit regions and hold town-hall meetings with different citizens residing in regions. The aim of these town-hall meetings is to disseminate the constitution and to gather data as regards the views and opinions of society with respect to theirknowledge about their constitutional rights. MoPCA will also undertake consultative meetings in all regions.

title: CO-Enhancing Resilience in Somaliland II
description:
Specific objective/ Outcome:  Sustainably improve food security and livelihoods of Somali people, households, communities through effective risk management, protection of productive assets, improved governance of resilience structures, and promotion of innovations and evidence based programming.
Intermediary Outcome 1: Improved capacity of households to implement disaster risk management and positive coping strategies to mitigate the immediate effect of exposure to shock.
Intermediary Outcome 2: Improved capacity of individuals, households and communities to adhere to positive development trajectories; despite exposures to shocks and utilize strategies designed to allow adaptation to rapid and slow on-set hazards.
Intermediary Outcome 3: Improved capacity to engage in strategies for sustainable livelihoods and economic growth to enhance food security and resilience

title: CO-Somalia Desert Locust Response Projec
description:
Specific objective:  To curb the spread of Desert Locust, pprotect and recover Livelihoods of the people affected by Locust disaster in Somaliland and Puntland.
Result 1: Improved locust control mechanisms and capacitate/enable government and local community to minimize negative effects on livelihoods of people affected by desert locust.
Result 2: Reduced impact of desert locust and support early livelihood recovery through provision critical agriculture inputs and livestock fodder.
Activities
1.1. Support 10 community mobilization campaigns and trainings at ground level, on locust control.
1.2. 600 people undertake mechanical control (digging trenches and driving hopper bands into them) through cash for work
1.3. 3 community awareness campaigns through media outlets, reaching 24 villages with an average population of 350 HHs each (8500HHs to be reached through awareness and outreach on locust).
1.4        Conduct one baseline, and one Post Distribution Monitoring.

title: Increasing  Agricultural Production
description:
Oxfam has rehabilitated dozens of boreholes in Sool and Sanaag region, most of those water structure has solar system in place. Oxfam#s assessment found pout that some of those structures are not used by people due to varying reasons. Oxfam EFSVL and WASH team discussed this issue and propose we combine water and agricultural production. Oxfam will support ministry of agriculture to assess 6-7 water points in those two regions aimed to start agricultural production. The government will mobilize communities and familiarizethem agricultural production. It is expected that linking existing water sites to agriculture will improve nutritional. Mionistry of agriculture will enhane agricultural practices by introducing agriculture around those water points. The ministry will provide seeds, knowledge regularly using its field staff.
Nutrition-Sensitive Agriculture is good-based approach to agricultural development that puts nutritionally rich foods, dietary diversity and food fortification at the heart of overcoming malnutrition and micronutrientdeficiencies. This assignment focuses on the utilization of water resource for agriculture sector to improve the nutritional value of foods for good nutrition, health and productivity, and social significance of farming and supporting rural livelihood specially that pregnant, lactating women and child.
# The main objective of this mission is to investigate the suitability of borehole water resource for utilization for irrigation purpose.
# Understanding Perception of the community for benefiting water for agriculture purpose
# The MOAD consultants will observe the appropriateness of nature of land (soil type, topography, soil nutrient) for crop production and predict the method of irrigation that could be used.
# During the field exercise, the consultants will analyze the proper ways of community water allocation for domestic use, animal watering and irrigation.
# The consultants will investigate the current situation of agricultural production status and level of nutrition of beneficiaries# community.
# Consultants will have soil and water samples

title: CO-Desert Locust Crisis Response
description:
Specific objective:  To curb the spread of Desert Locust, pprotect and recover Livelihoods of the people affected by Locust disaster in Somaliland and Puntland.
Result 1: Improved locust control mechanisms and capacitate/enable government and local community to minimize negative effects on livelihoods of people affected by desert locust.
Result 2: Reduced impact of desert locust and support early livelihood recovery through provision critical agriculture inputs and livestock fodder

title: CO-Somalia Locust Control Measures
description:
Oxfam has been working in Somalia for over 40 years, working with Somali people and organisations implementing humanitarian, resilience and development programmes. Humanitarian response focuses on WaSH, EVFSL and Protection.
Oxfam has made a lot of gains through humanitarian resilience programmes which are likely to be eroded if the desert locust menace is uncontrolled. Oxfam will therefore capitalise and work with the existing community structures such as Early Warning Committees, Government line ministries, FAO and other stakeholders on the preventive and control measures.
Oxfam will prioritize safeguarding livelihoods focusing on cash intervention and locust control measures.

A total of 1,056 people in coastal areas of Sool region will be reachedby the project and supported toprotect and recover their livelihoods.

Oxfam has vast experience in implementing conditional and unconditional cash transfer approaches in WASH, EVFSL programmes. The project will specifically focus on the Cash for Work(CfW) approach as it not only empowers individuals to spend based on their priority needs but also focuses on revamping community assets. CfW will therefore stimulate the recovery of the local economy by creating short-term work, reintroduce income flow,supporting local businesses through the purchase worktools while also encouraging households to purchase food and non-food items locally. The trench digging will involve large numbers of the population and will be designed to encourage the integration and participation of women and other marginalized groups in an area thus benefitting the entire community and not just a few individuals.

The project will support communities to address locust spread by burying them in trenches excavated through cash for work. A total of 1,056 people will dig 26 km of trenches and drive hopper bands through cash for work, this task will continue for 30 days, 15 days per month starting in mid-March 2020. This task is expected to minimize hopper bands probability to turn to dangerous swarm level while at the same time communities will be able to access cash to help them address food insecurity situation at household level.

Oxfam will closely cooperate with the Somaliland Ministry of agriculture

title: CO-COVID-19 Help Line
description:
a. Receive and make calls to the application through existing three-digit toll free short code.
b. Manages region-based calls and direct to appropriate call centers in the six Somaliland regions.
c. Customize existing application to handle multiple calls at the same time.
d. Provide an option for callers to access up to date information on the virus based on the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines through toll free number (Telesom will cover Short code and calling minutes).
e. Provide Symptoms screening checker to all callers to answer few questions over the phone to determine whether they at risk and provide appropriate advice.
f.  Speak to caller center operator for further information and support.
2. Assisting capacitate the existing call center in Hargeisa and establish additional 5 call centers with three health workers manning each call center.
3. Train the call center staff to manage the help line platform, receive calls, process audio messages and call back people who could not get through. Provide regular reports to committee and potential high risks cases for action when the times comes.
4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic.
5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.

The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines.
A total of 18 call center staff volunteers from the Ministry of Health will be trained through a two days workshop in Hargeisa to train them on the platform and dealing with callers during this difficult time. Three call center volunteers will be selected from each of the six main regions in Somaliland including Marodijeex, Awdal, Saxil, Todgheer, Sool and Sanaag. Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

title: CO-Desert Locust - Joint Response
description: The Desert Locust Joint Response is a 6 month emergency response project focusing on FSL and Cash interventions to control the spread of locust and support communities (agropastoralists and pastoralists) in coping with the loss of livelihoods due to locust invasions. All activities will be accompanied by COVID-19 WASH preparedness interventions, focusing on Public Health Promotion and the distribution of hygiene items. SOS Somaliland is the lead for this Joint Response (DRA). Oxfam will deliver the project with partners Candlelight and KAALO, who will work in Eastern Somaliland and Puntland (Togdheer, Sool, Nugal). Oxfam will respond in Awdal and Togdheer.

title: CO-COVID-19 Pandemic Support
description:
Description of the crisis (including number of affected, timeline, number of affected Oxfam has reached to date etc):
COVID-19 (Coronavirus acute respiratory disease) was first identified in late 2019 in Wuhan in Hubei province, China, and has since spread globally, resulting in the ongoing pandemic. While there are so far only seven laboratory-confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Somalia (first case: 16 March 2020), it must be noted there are no testing facilities and tests are currently sent to South Africa. Results are received after two weeks. The country has only 15 intensive care unit beds and ranks 194th out of 195 in the Global Health Security Index. Over a third of Somalis do not have enough clean, safe water to meet their daily needs, let alone for more frequent preventive handwashing. It goes without saying that an outbreak of COVID-19 in Somalia would have a devastating impact on vulnerable communities who already suffer from drought, conflict and most recently, locust invasion. 6.3 million Somalis are food insecure, 2.1 million internally displaced. The below activities would provide Oxfam Somalia and our partners with a top-up to the 50,000 GBP recently received through the CAT Fund.
Project description / activities (including numbers to be reached):
An additional 100,000 GBP (50% as loan, 50% as grant) will enable Oxfam and our partners to scale up the WASH preparedness activities as well as support partner Shaqodoon on extending the COVID-19 helpline to Somalia#s Puntland State. Shaqodoon are currently in the process of completing the set-up of the helpline in Somaliland (with support from the current CAT Fund grant); to be launched by 11th April. The helpline in Puntland willfollow the same process as in Somaliland: Shaqodoon will develop the system and link it to a toll-free Coronavirus hotline providedby Puntland#s Ministry of Health. The Ministry of Health will work closely with WHO and identify health personnel who will be trained in receiving and processing calls. Shaqodoon will provide pre-recorded health messages, on-site technical support and data analysis/dashboards for the Ministry.

The remaining amount will be utilised to scale up COVID-19 preparedness activities in Somaliland and Puntland, in collaboration with partners. Itwill also be used to top-up partners# crisis modifiers from other donors to make theircontribution in this fight, more meaningful. Activities include set-up of handwashing points in settlements, purchase and distribution of hygiene kits to IDP communities, dispatching mobile teams to disinfect busy public areas and purchase of HTH chlorine pumps for disinfection.

50,000 people will be reached by Oxfam#s and partners# WASH COVID-19 preparedness activities.
Shaqodoon through the Ministry of Health of Puntland hopes to reach a majority of Puntland#s phone users with COVID-19 information sharing and prevention messaging.
